articles.headline: In Settlement’s Fine Print, Goldman May Save $1 Billion
articles.snippet: Goldman is the last of the big American banks to settle an inquiry into how Wall Street worsened the mortgage bubble and ensuing financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Goldman is the last of the big American banks to settle an inquiry into how Wall Street worsened the mortgage bubble and ensuing financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: State and federal officials said on Monday that Goldman Sachs would pay $5.1 billion to settle accusations of wrongdoing before the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Marine’s Death in a Secret Iraqi Base Reflects a Quietly Expanding U.S. Role
articles.snippet: New information from U.S. military officials after the death of Staff Sgt. Louis F. Cardin also raised questions about President Obama’s pledge to keep troops out of combat there.
articles.abstract: New information from U.S. military officials after the death of Staff Sgt. Louis F. Cardin also raised questions about President Obama’s pledge to keep troops out of combat there.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a Saturday morning three weeks ago, American radar detected rockets headed for a secret fire base of about 100 Marines in northern Iraq.

articles.headline: For Indian Start-Ups, Tenacity Beats High Tech
articles.snippet: Venture capitalists looking to fund start-ups in India place more emphasis on execution than on intellectual property.
articles.abstract: Venture capitalists looking to fund start-ups in India place more emphasis on execution than on intellectual property.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — On a hot afternoon in a two-story house here, as dogs barked and auto-rickshaws sputtered outside, a venture capitalist grilled three entrepreneurs.

articles.headline: For a Generalist, ‘Too Big to Fail’ May Be Too Tricky to Judge
articles.snippet: The judge who ruled on MetLife’s designation as “too big to fail” is a legal rock star. But financial oversight isn’t her area of expertise.
articles.abstract: The judge who ruled on MetLife’s designation as “too big to fail” is a legal rock star. But financial oversight isn’t her area of expertise.
articles.lead_paragraph: About two years ago, I was speaking with an executive at MetLife who floated the idea that the company should sue the government to overturn its designation as a firm that was too big to fail. The company believed that it was being unfairly labeled, and that the regulations that came with the designation were hindering its business.

articles.headline: Barrage of Attack Ads Threatens to Undermine Donald Trump
articles.snippet: More than half of the record spending on negative advertising during the 2016 presidential primary has been directed at a single candidate, Mr. Trump.
articles.abstract: More than half of the record spending on negative advertising during the 2016 presidential primary has been directed at a single candidate, Mr. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than half of the record spending on negative advertising during the 2016 presidential primary has been directed at a single candidate, Donald J. Trump, a barrage that threatens to undermine his candidacy even as he continues to march toward the Republican nomination.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Chinese Scions’ Song: My Daddy’s Rich and My Lamborghini’s Good-Looking
articles.snippet: Many wealthy Chinese are moving their families and riches to Western cities like Vancouver, where their children show off cars and diamond-encrusted watches.
articles.abstract: Many wealthy Chinese are moving their families and riches to Western cities like Vancouver, where their children show off cars and diamond-encrusted watches.
articles.lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Andy Guo, an 18-year-old Chinese immigrant, loves driving his red Lamborghini Huracán. He does not love having to share the car with his twin brother, Anky.

articles.headline: European Union Calls for Big Companies to Disclose More Tax Data
articles.snippet: The proposed rules, in the works before the Panama Papers leak, are intended in some ways to lift the veil on similar types of corporate secrets.
articles.abstract: The proposed rules, in the works before the Panama Papers leak, are intended in some ways to lift the veil on similar types of corporate secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union officials on Tuesday waded into the fight against international tax dodging, calling for the world’s biggest companies to disclose more data about their tax arrangements with the bloc’s member governments and to share information about offshore havens where they shelter money.

articles.headline: Documents Undercut U.S. Case for Taking Mortgage Giant Fannie Mae’s Profits
articles.snippet: Government lawyers said they changed the terms of a bailout deal to protect taxpayers, but newly unsealed documents call that into question.
articles.abstract: Government lawyers said they changed the terms of a bailout deal to protect taxpayers, but newly unsealed documents call that into question.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a Friday in August 2012, the federal government changed the terms of its bailout of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, sending all the mortgage finance giants’ profits to the Treasury. The surprise decision prompted a lawsuit from shareholders, who argued that the collection of profits was an improper taking of private property without compensation.
